useful AI, and you’re on your way.2. master one distribution channel. pick your niche’s top platform and lock into one format that works. post daily, and use claude to analyze the best posts in that physical products look for 40k+ followers and high engagement rates bonus if they're already promoting other appsthe big insight here is way easier to sell $4.99 app to a stranger than a $49 pillow to pages.v0 for mockups, get inspiration from top app store screenshots, and set up a waitlist + a simple validation survey. throw ~$50 into tiktok ads to see if your copy converts before committing resources.5. keep the build stack lean v0 for UI, claude for code, openai for AI features, and revenue cat for payments. minimize overhead so you can iterate fast and keep costs low.6. scale and rinselaunch a related app and cross-promote with the first one. bundle pricing to lock users in and reuse your creator network to scale even faster.congratulations, you didn’t just build an app—you yesterday, i stumbled onto the most underrated market research tool.tiktok creator insights.it's a goldmine of consumer behavior data, hiding in plain sight. and it's free to use.here's why it's powerful:1. shows you what people are desperately searching for2. highlights topics with high demand but low supply3. reveals trending questions in every industry4. tracks search growth over 14-day periodsthe "content gap" tab shows you problems people are actively trying to solve, but can't find good solutions for.so that's cool for a couple reasons1. help you create content that has low supply/high demand (better chances of going viral)2. you can build startups to some of these trendsExample:i searched "email management" and found:• "how to clear 10k emails"• "best way to organize work inbox"• "email templates for busy people"thousands searching.hardly any solutions.the beauty of this• it's real-time market research• it's actual user intent• it's completely free• and most founders aren't using ita bunch of smart founders are mining tiktok insights right now it isn't perfect, but you never know what you might findyour next startup idea might be hiding in those search trends.So, ill share how to access it because it’s kinda hidden:1. Go to TT search2.Type in “creator search insight”3. Tap viewthis is how i use iti scroll through suggested/trending tapi see if anything catches my eyei look to see search data sometimes ill look for demographic datai write notes on what i learnand i see what are related videosthat sparks ideas for mefree ideas galore.im one of those people that think using data like this is your unfair advantage.if tiktok is the new search engine, then tiktok creator insights is the new google trends.might as well use it.sometimes you don't need to overthink startups1. find content gaps2. fill the gap3. listen to what people want4. build an mvp5. iterate based on how they like it6. charge more than what it costs you7. repeatfor more insights like this, subscribe to gregisenberg.com while it's still free

i was wrong about indie startups. i can explain in 2 minutes.i've been thinking a lot about arc browser lately. it's probably my favorite piece of software built recently.but they just announced they're building a new ai-first browser. the original arc is basically on life support.for the makers of arc, this is about scaling their business.building a beautiful ui on top of chromium might get you a great product. but it won't get you to $100b.i get it.arc built something tech twitter fell in love with. including me. it's my daily driver.but being well-loved isn't enough when you're vc-backed. you need to reinvent the category.and that's okay. because here's what i've learned:reinventing a category is a vc-backed startup game.cash flow is an indie game.never forget that.it's a pattern i see everywhere:notion trades simplicity for ai dreams and a mailboxwordpress battles lawyers while ghost picks upi call it the "mirror effect":every time a vc startup is forced to reinvent, they create a $1-100m opportunity for indie founders.the math is simple:• vcs need billion-dollar exits • small markets don't work • original users get abandoned • someone needs to serve them smart indie founders don't compete with vc dreams.they inherit the forgotten users.the playbook is obvious:1. build what made the original special. 2. serve the users who hate "progress." 3. stay "small" and profitable. you don't need to be a unicorn when you're making $10m arr with 80% margins.sell that business for $50m-$100m. no investors.there's a fortune in forgotten users.and they're just waiting for someone to serve them.i love arc. i hope it stays. but if it changes course, someone will continue that legacy.maybe it should be you.i used to think indie startups had to avoid competition with giants, but now i see they can win by embracing the forgotten markets.some of the best opportunities aren't in the "next big thing."they're in the markets vcs consider too small.while everyone else chases billionsyou can build a beautiful business serving the forgotten millions.no right or wrong approach.choose what excites you the most.go big or go home.or go small or go home.each is beautiful in its own way.what game do you want to pick?i give away startup ideas and growth tactics at gregisenberg.comits free to subscribe for now

Most founders panic when their product flops. They slash prices. Run desperate promos. Eventually shut down.But there's another way.When a product fails in its intended market, you have two options:1. Die slowly trying to force it2. Embrace the rejection and find a new narrativeLook at what Crocs did:• Started as boat shoes• Rejected by boaters• Embraced by chefs, nurses, kids• Now they're "ugly-cool" fashionOr Cognac:• Failed as French wine competitor• Embraced by hip-hop culture• Became luxury status symbol• Now it's a $3B+ marketIf I'm Apple, here's the play:• Partner with Jony Ive for limited edition• Get Murakami to design custom frames• Raise price to $5,000• Make it art, not techBecause what's more valuable:A failed mass market product, or a collector's item that makes people fall more in love with your brand?Sometimes your "failure" is just your product finding its true purpose.Not as the next iPhone.But as the frame in collectors' homes that drives word of mouth and high margins.Gets you thinking, doesn't it?--If you're looking for free startup ideas, ive got a database full of 30+ of them https://lnkd.in/eKicBBqe

The "80/20 principle" for foundersTraction: 80% distribution, 20% productGrowth: 80% retention, 20% acquisitionRevenue: 80% existing customers, 20% new leadsPricing experiments: 80% positioning tweaks, 20% actual price changesBrand building: 80% customer experience, 20% logo designSales: 80% listening, 20% pitchingCommunity building: 80% empowering users, 20% company-led initiativesProduct: 80% core features, 20% nice-to-havesTime: 80% executing, 20% strategizingInsights: 80% user feedback, 20% user behaviorPricing: 80% value perception, 20% actual costsMarketing: 80% word-of-mouth, 20% paid adsUser onboarding: 80% aha moments, 20% feature tutorialsUI/UX: 80% intuitive flow, 20% aesthetic appealViral growth: 80% reducing friction, 20% incentivizing sharingRoadmap: 80% market pull, 20% vision pushTeam management: 80% context setting, 20% direct ordersCustomer interviews: 80% observing, 20% askingMarket positioning: 80% owning a niche, 20% broad appealFounder time: 80% working on the business, 20% in the businessPrioritize the 80% that moves the needle. The rest is just noise.For how to do this, sign up to gregisenberg.com now for free startup ideas and frameworks while it's still free =)

How to grow your startup (19 ideas that actually work)1. Expired domain goldmine. Find high-DA dead sites, rebuild with AI content. Rank for killer terms in weeks. 2. Viral review bounty pages. Add a page on your website “we pay for viral reviews”. $100 for 50k views, $200 for 100k. Cheaper than ads, 10x more authentic. 3. Launch 1 micro-app per month, not one big one. Free.  Cross-promote like crazy. Layer on paid ones after you have traction.4. Craft killer weekly data reports. The press eats it up and you get tons of backlinks and free traffic5. Dead YouTube channel arbitrage. Buy, update links, reupload. Huge arbitrage opportunity right now. A friend of mine bought 10k subs and 100k monthly views for $500. Passive lead gen on steroids.6. Free template downloads. Notion, Shopify, Webflow whatever your use-case is. Custom template for ideal users. 50k+ downloads, each a qualified lead. You’ll want to charge but make it free. Worth it.7. Build in public, but make it a game. Feature voting board + leaderboard. Free insights, users feel like co-founders.8. Comparison site empire. Launched 20 niche "[Product] Alternatives" sites. Rank for competitor terms, funneled high-intent traffic to you.9.  "Best Of" industry directories. Built top 100 lists for every niche in our industry. SEO goldmine.10. FOMO-driven invites. "Get 1 month free, invite 5 friends, 24-hour expiry." Growth loop from hell (in a good way).11. Chrome extension trojan horse. Fix popular app's UI, funnel users to your product.12. Gamify everything. Onboarding, referrals, feature unlocks. Users compete, you win.13. Ultra-premium upsell. Launch 10x price tier with concierge onboarding. Only 1% convert, funds the entire free plan.14. Geo-arbitrage pricing. Charge by local cost of living. Explode in emerging markets.15. 2+ feature gates. "Invite 3 friends to unlock this feature." Your best customers will invite. Free growth.16. Cross-app bundles. Partner with not direct competitors but a similar customer base.17. Resource directory arbitrage. Create free resource libraries for adjacent industries. Tons of backlinks, 10% of traffic converts to your product.18. Look at the best performing ads on TikTok. Apply to your niche.19. Interactive annual report. Think Spotify Wrapped for B2B. People share like crazy. Might get 100k social impressions in a day. Turn into a directory of them. Free organic traffic.

The internet can be your prison or paradise. Depends how you use it.I got an email from this 18-year-old kid in Nebraska. Raised by a single mom in a town of like 500. WiFi was his lifeline to the world.Most people get trapped in the scroll vortex. Watching lives, not living them. But this guy vowed to use the internet to escape his tough situation.He dove into coding. Self-taught with YouTube videos. Haunted Reddit threads for business ideas. Eventually, he built a SaaS app.He had like 10 customers for a year.  Was losing hope. Couldnt even pay SaaS bills with it but kept at it.He started to recruit affiliates. And they helped promote it. Then SEO started kicking in. And he had a few viral social posts.Now he's pulling in $28k a month. And he got an offer from his dream company to buy his company.Life-changing money, sure, but the confidence boost i think is priceless.Guy turned his phone into an escape pod in just 20 months. He'll never be the same again again.Went from corn fields to code fields without leaving his bedroom.No fancy Stanford degree.No Silicon Valley connections. Guy's never even been to San Francisco. Calls it "San Fran" and "Siliconeeeee Valley" cause he doesn't know any better. You love to see it.Not saying everyone can pull this off. But it fires me up when people use the internet to launchpad into a new world. The internet is either your holy grail or your black hole. All comes down to which way you're swiping.

Founder rules:The reason founders fail to scale is they believe they should do everything, rather than understanding why they can'tBurnout comes not from working too little, but from working on the wrong things too muchWhen we're frustrated with our startup's progress, we have no patience with our team's pace (founder's dilemma)Don’t surround yourself with pessimistic people. Absolute vibe killer in entrepreneurship.Visionary founders want to build the future. Executioner founders want to optimize the present.Product-market fit is in the metrics - product-founder fit is in the mirrorWe think ideas are brilliant when we don't understand the market, and obvious when we doAre you chasing investors because you want validation or money?If you can bootstrap, you probably should.You can't reason with an unreasonable market, only pivot to a reasonable oneA competitor is a potential acquirer you haven't partnered with yet as a co-founder is a friend you haven't fought with yetYour first idea is rarely your best idea - it's the catalyst for your best ideaThe loudest customer feedback is often the least valuable - listen to the silent majorityRevenue solves all problems - except the ones it createsThe best marketing strategy is an exceptional product - but it's not enough on its ownYour pricing strategy is your business strategy - underpricing is slow suicideChurn is a feature, not a bug - it should dictate your product roadmap The most valuable feature is the one you remove - simplicity scales, complexity crawlsYour biggest competitor isn't another startup - it's customer indifference and lack of distribution Have fun with whatever you’re doingfor more startup ideas and frameworks, go to gregisenberg.com and hit subscribe

I'M FEELING SPICY. I’ll say the quiet part out loud:1. You don’t need 2 monitors to work. One is fine.2. Stripe MRR screenshots only attract people into Stripe MRR screenshots.3. Rocket reach should be illegal. They sell your phone number and email address to strangers who bombard you.4. Most startup perks are just golden handcuffs disguised as culture. 5. The stock you own in the VC-backed company you work at is probably worthless. You just find out too late. Hedge your bets. 6. Too much fighting in startup land. Public fights. This isn’t WWE. Bad look. More love.7. VC is basically only deep tech or AI at this point. Really hard to understand why you should take VC money at this point unless you can’t bootstrap.8. More founders want to be like Pieter Levels than probably any other founder right now. Much to the chagrin of VCs (even though they want to be him too lol).9. There is no middle class creator. Either you’re making $500k+ or barely anything from content.10. Your best employees check slack on the weekend at least once. “Is everything okay”11. It’s still low status to be a creator in business world except for a few exceptions. Surprisingly because it’s free distribution and distribution is the moat now.12. Some of the most popular startup advice from billionaire tech founder to founders hurts more than helps bootstrapped businesses.13. The majority of tweets/linkedin posts are plagiarized at this point.14.  Most creator-led agencies are zombie companies. Creators took massive amount equity. Didn’t operate. Promoted them. Claimed high ARR. Business went down, creators lost interest.15. Buying a laundromat is a bad idea for 99.9% of people. If you can build software why are you buying a laundromat? Am I on crazy pills?16. Every major city smells like weed. Just an observation17. Drip coffee at home is treated as a second class citizen. It's equally as good as your $7 cup of ethiopian blend that tastes like vinegar.18. Alcohol is back. You can go have one drink with your buddy and it probably won't kill you. 19. today, i had one of those days every founder knows wellyou’re deep in the thick of growing your startup when, out of nowhere, it hits you—clarityyou don't always expect it in that moment, but sup, nice to see you again old friend.it might strike in the shower or sauna or while in a team meeting, you never know.but suddenly, you see everything what you’ve been doing wrong and exactly what needs to happen next. everything just clicks:- that feature you’ve been obsessing over. useless. kill it- the marketing channel you ignored. it’s a goldmine. double down- the "best practices" you followed from that expert. purism, not progress. ditch ityou see where your business could be in 10 years—and also in 12 months. probably the most important timelines to be able to see where you're going. long term and short term.and right then, it’s clear: all that matters is staying on this path. Build wealth for your team and have a blast doing it.I think of it as "startup puberty".painful, awkward, but completely necessary.I used to make excuses when I had some clarity. “let’s give it another quarter.” “one more A/B test.” “but [insert tech giant] is doing it!” “we saw some growth this month.”but tough decisions are tough for a reason. the move is to zoom out, get existential, and ask yourself: 1. what have I really learned? 2. what am I really building? 3. would we even be in this business knowing what we know now?Or are we just optimizing our MySpace page while Facebook is being born?savage, i know.one thing i've learned iswhen clarity hits, embrace it. follow it like your life depends on it.because in startupland, clarity without action is just expensive journaling.And who wants that.for more startup stories like this, sign up to gregisenberg.com

so yesterday, i meet this entrepreneur and they hit me with the line 'we don't do ads. all our growth is 100% organic'and there's this awkward pause... you know the one. they're waiting for me to go 'wow, you're so pure and noble'but in my head i'm like 'weird flex but ok'look, i get it. starting organic is smart. build that audience, community, newsletter and put in the hard work. i always start organic personally.but acting like never touching ads is some kinda entrepreneur merit badge feels off to me.ads aren't the devil. they're a tool. a pretty damn useful one at that.let me break it down:1. ads force you to nail your messaging. you can't afford to be wishy-washy when you're paying for eyeballs.2. you gotta create optimized landing pages for different audiences. suddenly you're learning about your market segments real quick.3. you get hard data on what actually works, not just what you think works. your gut feeling means jack when the numbers are staring you in the face.if you find profitable channels, why the hell wouldn't you pour gas on that fire?but it's not just about the wins. even the Ls are valuable. bad ads tell you what doesn't work before you waste months or years scaling the wrong thing.don't get me wrong, i'm not saying 'ads or die'. but i am saying don't close doors just to feel superior.as founders we need to use every tool in the box. test, learn, iterate.that gives us the most amount leverage. helps us in case we don't want to raise vc, helps us when we want to sell, helps us sleep at night.your 'organic only' policy might be costing you more than your first ad campaign ever would.note: i recommend boringads.com if youre looking for an agency that will build profitable ad campaigns. they use ai/their own software to help optimized. they are waitlist only at the moment. loved it so much, i invested.

YouTube JUST announced this new thing called Hype and it's lowkey geniusimagine you're scrolling and see a wonderful video from some small creator. you wanna do more than just like or share. enter Hype. okay, here's how it works you get 3 "Hypes" a week to boost videos you dig. it's like a supercharged upvote. more Hypes = higher on a special leaderboard.but here's the thingit only works for creators under 500K subs and vids less than a week old. plus there's a "small creator bonus" so the little guys can compete.why's this smart1. turns passive viewers into active supporters (people want to support the up and comers!)2. gives smaller creators a shot at blowing up3. YouTube gets more engagement without messing with the algorithm4. promotes niches so everything isn't watching the same thing (increase watch time)"In just the first four weeks of our beta tests in Turkey, Taiwan, and Brazil, users hyped over 5 million times across more than 50,000 unique channels" - YT Teamit's not about killing the big creators. it's about giving the underdogs a chance to be seen.it currently being tested let's be real, social's been feeling stale. same big accounts, same content, rinse and repeat.you either dont get seen or you go ballistic. Hype. it's like CPR for the internet dream. suddenly, that person making weird videos in their bedroom could be tomorrow's viral sensation.just like the good ole days.it's bringing back that wild west vibe of early YouTube. when any random video could blow up overnight.i totally can see a hype-type feature for platforms like X/Twitter too. i hope it takes off.it's about keeping the internet weird, creative, and unpredictable.so yeah, Hype might just save us from an endless feed of polished corporate content and put the "social" back in social media. maybe its the domino we need to get other social platforms to do the same.let's see who/what the internet decides to make famous next.time to make the internet weird again.

I'm playing with the weirdest new viral social app. It's called SocialAI.Imagine X/Twitter, but you have millions of followers.  Except the catch is they are all AI. You have 0 human followers.Here's how it works:You post a status update. Could be anything."I'm thinking of quitting my job to start a llama farm."Instantly, you get thousands of replies. All AI-generated.Some offer encouragement:"Follow your dreams! Llamas are the future of sustainable agriculture."Others play devil's advocate:"Have you considered the economic viability of llama farming in your region?"It's like having a personal board of advisors, therapists, and cheerleaders. All in your pocket.The creator calls it a "tool for therapy, journaling, or simply feeling heard."But here's where it gets interesting:It's addictive. Really addictive.I found myself posting more and more. Craving that instant hit of attention and feedback.It felt good. Too good.I can see how some people might prefer AI followers to real people. They always said the right thing. They were always there. And this is the harsh truth about social:Most people don't get heard on social. They scream into a void and no one pays attention.Is this the future of social media? A personalized echo chamber where we're all the main character in our own show?Or is it a dark mirror, reflecting our deepest insecurities and need for validation? I'm not sure. But I see the appeal.What do you think? Would you try it? Or does the idea of an AI-powered social network make you want to throw your phone in the ocean?I'm genuinely curious. Do you hate it or love it.

My Jewish identity was a secret I carried, never letting it see the light of day.Why?Maybe it was fear. Fear of judgment, of being "different" in the business world. Maybe I'd lose that big deal, big hire etc. Let's be real, it was definitely that.But here's the thing:Since when did authenticity become taboo? Are there really rules against being yourself? If you're not hurting anyone, isn't it all about peace and love?And the reality is it probably won't affect your business. Your investors, team, sales prospects should respect you. Might even respect you even more for being yourself.This post won't break any engagement records. It might even attract some negativity.But if it inspires just one person to embrace who they are, it's worth it.Life's too short for masks. Your uniqueness? That's your superpower.So here I am, wrapping tefillin (thx Yossi), proudly Jewish. I feel like a weight off my shoulders.Who are you, really? And isn't it time the world knew?

How to find startup ideas:When I was in college, I wanted to start a startup. As a broke college kid, I figured B2B would be a better place to start than B2C.So I booked a middle seat flight to San Francisco on a Visa card.Why SF? My buddy worked at this BigCorp there, and I had a hunch that where there's big business, there's big opportunity.I sweet-talked my way into shadowing him for a week. "Just pretend I'm not here," I told everyone. But trust me, I was watching everything.For five days straight, I was a sponge. I asked questions. I observed. I listened. And boy, did I learn.In those big offices, amidst the bustle of important people doing important things, I saw cracks. Inefficiencies. Frustrations. Problems hiding in plain sight that everyone had just accepted as "the way things are."It was like stumbling into a goldmine of B2B startup ideas. Each pain point, each clunky process, each exasperated sigh from an employee was a potential million-dollar opportunity.I built and launched a B2B app in 30 days. It started to gain traction.The next summer, I wanted to learn B2C.And if there's one thing I learned from my SF adventure, it's that real insights come from real experiences.So I packed my bags again. This time, destination: Paris.Why Paris? Why not. It's a world apart from Silicon Valley, and that was exactly what I needed - a fresh perspective.For a month, I lived like a Parisian. I walked the cobblestone streets, sipped espresso at corner cafes, and rode the metro. But more importantly, I watched. I observed how people lived, worked, and played. I soaked in the culture, the habits, the daily routines.And somewhere between the Louvre and a quaint bistro in Montmartre, it hit me - a social startup idea that could only have been born from this immersive experience.Here's the thing I realized through these adventures:The best way to find a B2B startup idea: Go travel to a big company and find their issues. Prioritize them. They're there. You just need to look.And for a consumer startup idea - Go travel and observe. Live in a different culture. See how people interact with the world around them.And if you dont want to take a flight... there's tons of tools like Google Trends and mining social data tools that are kinda like travelling to different communities without actually traveling.Once you find that idea, move fast. I designed and shipped both my B2B and B2C ideas within 30 days. They weren't perfect, but they were real - and that's what counts.--I've got a database of 30+ free startup ideas, if you want them here https://lnkd.in/eKicBBqe

Back in 2017, Islands (my chat startup) was dying a slow death. No one cared. We were forgettable.We raised $2M but money was running out.I had a make-or-break meeting with one of our VCs in an hour, and I knew he was going to ask the million-dollar question: "How are you going to grow?"Most founders would've spouted off about AI, blockchain, or some other buzzword bingo. And to be honest, I thought about it. It was the ICO craze of 2017. Maybe adding a token would be the answer to my problems.But I had a different plan brewing, one that would either launch us to the moon or get me laughed out of the boardroom.It was the gentle 'whoosh' of my MacBook waking up that did it. That sound was pure satisfaction. Why couldn't our app deliver the same hit of dopamine?That's what our app was missing: Sound.While every other app was as silent as a librarian's fever dream, I wanted to make noise - literally.So I'd called up this indie musician in Montreal I went to elementary school with and gave him a mission: "Create a notification sound that'll make people's heads turn."The morning of my VC meeting, I woke up to a text that nearly made me spit out my coffee:"Bought, opened and emptied three coconuts for recording last night lol"This madman had turned his tiny Montreal apartment into a tropical thunderdome, all for a 2-second audio clip that cost me $280 and probably his security deposit. As I walked into the VC's office, palms sweaty, coconuts heavy, I steeled myself for the inevitable question."So," he leaned back in his chair, "how exactly do you plan to grow in this crowded market?"I took a deep breath and said the words that would either make or break us:"Two words: Coconut sounds."His eyes rolled so hard I thought they might fall out of his head. "Focus on the big things," he growled. But I couldn't shake this feeling. Sometimes, it's the little things that make the biggest waves.We pushed the update that night and held my breath. For a whole day, nothing. I was ready to eat crow, to admit my VC was right.But then, something magical happened.Our user numbers started ticking up. Slowly at first, then faster. Word of mouth exploded."Have you heard Islands' notification sound? It's crazy!" It was like we'd captured lightning in a bottle. Or should I say, a coconut.It didn't make our product, but it certainely helped. Turned growth from swimming upstream to downstream.Nikita Bier says it best about how to grow startups:"My biggest learning has been that when you're launching a rocketship and you're off by 1mm, you'll miss the moon & land in space."Amen.I call it the "1mm rule:Find the small, quirky thing that makes people smile, share, and come back for more.Since then, every product decision I make starts with one question: "What's the coconut?" What small, possibly insane detail can we add that'll make users fall in love?(For more posts like this, sign up to gregisenberg.com)

I'm looking for business partners. People who want to build a portfolio of cash-flowing internet businesses. But first, some context. 4 years ago, I walked away from WeWork. I had sold my company to them, watching as they raised and then incinerated $20 billion. It was unbelievable. Painful.I vowed never to be part of something like that again. In the aftermath, I found myself at a crossroads. This was 2020 and the tech world was obsessed with chasing unicorns, but I wanted something different.Something sustainable.I spoke to the people I respected in Silicon Valley. And declared I wanted to build cash-flowing businesses and raise $0 of VC.They looked at me like I had three heads."You're going backwards," they said."You're wasting your time," they warned."You'll startups will eventually get crushed by VC-backed competition."Damn, lol.But I was tired of my fate hanging on a "yes" from VCs in Palo Alto. I craved control over my destiny.So, against all advice, I started Late Checkout, my holding company.It was profitable from day one - a stark contrast to my WeWork experience and a rarity in VC land.My goal - scale internet businesses powered by community, and on our own terms.The journey wasn't easy. We burned through millions and made more mistakes than I care to admit.But we persisted, and gradually, we cracked the code on scaling SaaS, marketplaces, and agencies.We discovered that the real power lies in building engaged audiences, fostering tight-knit communities, and finding creative ways to grow.Take our agency, latecheckout.agency for example. You've probably never heard of it, but we're pulling in clients at an average of $1 million per year creating the interfaces for lots of the AI products and non-AI products you use everyday.We did it all without a dime of VC money. Just one little funnel that works every single day.So, who am I looking for in a business partner:Maybe you're a solopreneur, and it's getting lonely. You've built something great, but you're hitting a ceiling.Or, you're running a VC-backed startup, but you're dreaming of turning it into a cash-flowing powerhouse. (And maybe buying out your VCs – I can help with that.)If any of these sound like you, here's what I'm offering:For businesses doing $500k-$5M, we could acquire a stake and scale it together.This isn't a distant, "call me quarterly" arrangement. We're in the trenches with you, day in and day out, helping you build something truly remarkable.This is the type of thing that sounds fun to me.And might sound fun to you.So here’s my ask of you:1) If this sounds like you DM me on X (not LinkedIn it'll get lost) and comment to this post. Ill respond to the most interesting ones2) If this isn’t you, all good. Like always, I’ll share my learnings along the way. It feels like internet startups are at a crossroads.More and more are choosing the non-VC route.Id love to work with you.

People who start VC-backed companies will spend $1.8M on a domain without launching a product and not even flinch.Challenge them on it, and they’ll say, “You think small.”It goes against what's natural. Maybe it works, and maybe that business becomes a billion dollar business. I don't know.But I can think of way more efficient ways to use $1.8M for a pre-traction startup. Investing in the product. Investing in the distribution.I gotta say, building cash-flowing businesses feels so much more natural. And I say this having built and sold 3 VC backed businesses.How most bootstrapped businesses start:You come up with a startup idea (probably after a couple drinks). You buy a $10 domain . You build an internet audience. People start following it.You build a product. People want it. You make your margin. Do some profit sharing. And keep compounding for as long as you possible can.Unlike VC-land where you can buy a $1.8M domain and its totally normal, cash-flow startups you scale as you go. The bigger bets come later.You think small first, big later. And it usually pays off.If you don't interrupt the compounding, you'll have no issues retiring with millions. This is a story I’ve never shared with anyone... January 2nd, 2019. I was broke.I had raised $2M in VC for my startup, but the bank account was empty. VCs had bailed.“Facebook will copy you,” they said.I was burning my savings to fund payroll. Desperate for an exit, I got a lead: an intro to an exec at TikTok. Let’s call her Sarah.She seemed interested in buying the company. LFG.Deals get done in person. So, I said, “I’ll be in LA later this week.”“Oh really? Yes, let’s meet,” she replied.Boom. There was a chance.I rented a Kia Soul—not a G-Wagon, but it would do. Hotel Tonight showed rooms at $500+, so I grabbed a Best Western in Pasadena, an hour from TikTok HQ but only $99/night.I arrived at 8 PM, had a cheap buffet dinner, and went to bed thinking, “Tomorrow is the day.”Next morning, I rushed to my Kia Soul and headed to the office.“I’m Greg Isenberg from Islands, here for Sarah,” I told her EA.“Have a seat right here.”My meeting was at 9 AM.9:05... 9:10... 9:25...“Is she coming?” I wondered.The EA approached. “Sarah can’t make it.”I asked to reschedule.“Sorry, we’ll get back to you.”I literally felt my heart burst in real time. I felt terrible.Time was ticking. Defeated, I walked back to my bright green Kia Soul with barely any gas. I emailed her, staying positive, and left my number.I got in the car, put it in drive, and headed north to San Francisco. Feeling defeated, I wondered what my girlfriend would think.As I got onto the I-5, an unknown number called. I answered.It was the TikTok exec. She apologized for missing the meeting and wanted to make a deal happen. “Can I intro you to the corp dev team?”I never sold to TikTok, but it got the M&A process rolling. I ended up with a few offers and did well. I even joined TikTok as an advisor when I didn't sell to them.It all worked out. And my team did well too. From the exit, they bought houses in NYC and brand new cars (most nicer than a Kia soul tbh)And I got my nest-egg back. Why I’m sharing this:1. Entrepreneurship is full of ups and downs. Here are a few lessons I learned:2. Stay positive when the world feels like it’s crashing down. You never know what might happen.3. Relying on VCs means you’re never truly in control. One moment you're everyone's darling, the next moment they leave you on read.4. Shoot your shot. Always.Startups aren’t all red roses and green cash, but they’re fun. Now, I focus on profitable, cash-flowing businesses—running agencies, internet communities, and SaaS products. Less stress.That startup experience aged me a decade. But here's the thing... you learn a lot about yourself and others through startups. I wouldn't have changed a thing. It's a beautiful thing.By the way, I put together 30+ profitable startup ideas that are pretty validated. You can grab them here totally free. Grab 'em while you can...https://lnkd.in/dGt8Cch4

Today, is Amazon Prime Day — they will generate ~$14B of sales in 2 days. It got me thinking... where is ecommerce headed over the next 10 years?The future of e-commerce (and how we all shop):1. Virtual assistants as personal shoppers that work 24/7. "Rufus" is Amazon's new shopper and is ridiculously helpful.2. Human customer support agents are the new luxury. Like getting a Perrier when you walk into a store.3. Amazon gets bigger, so your store has to get weirder. Weirder wins. 4. AI-curated personalized storefronts. Every storefront will feel like it's for you. Because it is for you.5. Gamified shopping experiences that turn every visit into a quest with rewards. Will feel more like Super Mario, than Wal-Mart.6. Time-sensitive offers and exclusive experiences. Keeps you coming back.7. Compete on community, not price. If you compete on price, you'll lose against Amazon. 8. Indie hackers rise as the new e-commerce entrepreneurs. No VCs, probably some Stripe loans etc9. User-generated product lines will drive mega traffic efficiently.10. Short-form videos and micro-documentaries that showcase a brand's lifestyle build affinity like no other. This will get more common.11. Super curated, super niche products based on lifestyles. You can't compete on selection anymore. Amazon will always win.12. Shift of power from big box retailers to big creators.13. Content first, commerce second is the new mantra. I need this as a poster.14. Immersive shopping experiences that make you feel part of the brand.15. Virtual reality shopping is coming but not for 5-10 years. But it will be huge.16. Monthly brand collaborations to keep product lines fresh. Your store doesnt end when you hit publish. Living and breathing thing.17. Post-purchase experiences determine brand loyalty. Everyone focuses on pre-purchase now, it's shifitng.18. SMS continues to be used more and more. But most  will abuse it. The ones that use it well will do really well.19. Spatial commerce makes shopping feel like using Figma.20. "Boring Marketing" strategies like AI-assisted SEO will drive growth.21. Creator-curated collections bring a personal touch to product lines.22. Mood-based recommendations match customers’ vibes at the moment. Make shopping impulsive.23. Vintage and second-hand items will be a new tab that keeps coming up.24. Micro-subscriptions for niche products keep customers engaged.25. Standout design makes your brand unforgettable. Ecommerce not just a sterile page. 26. Social proof as a currency—reviews, likes, and shares drive decisions. But they'll be videos not text.27. AI-assisted ads. Cheaper to get efficient ROAS. 28. Experience over product—sell the lifestyle, not just the item. All metrics go up when you do that.Where do you think e-commerce is headed?Happy Prime Day, everyone.Commerce is changing and it's changing fast.

There weren't many high paying jobs at the time. Money was tight for so many of the people I knewBut I wanted more, and through Gates, I figured out howThrough Bill, I discovered Warren Buffet and his jaw-dropping confession: "I read 600-1000 pages per day."Like a lightning bolt, it struck me - the path to world-class expertise, to foreseeing the future, was no secretIt was readingThat's when I committed to the 4% rule - dedicating an hour each day to readingA small daily investment with the potential to yield massive, compounding returns over time.The habit wasn't easy to form, but the resolve was unshakeableThis reading journey instilled in me a conviction that anyone, regardless of their starting point, could become an expert, a visionary, if they are willing to invest the time to read, to learnAnd my 4% time investment? Find the time."I agree.--I put together some free guides for people who want to build internet businesses on my website gregisenberg.com... enjoy.

New trend: "pay what you want" software I'm seeing it pop up almost every week on new projects.And I wouldn't be surprised if people saw conversion rates 2-3x when they switch from "pay monthly" to "pay what you want".Adds a ton of goodwill.It reminds me of Radiohead's 2007 experiment with their album "in rainbows". They did something BRILLIANT.Instead of selling the album, they did a pay as you want and even included in option to pay $0.At the time, it was unheard of. But the bet paid off big time.Over 1.2 million people downloaded it in the first month and they made WAY more money than their previous album.Sure, a bunch of people paid $0. And Radiohead needed to have zero ego about that. But it was worth it.Now we're applying that model to software businesses.Pay as you want is definitely more risk, but probably worth it for many high margin businesses.And occasionally you'll see a whale give you an wild amount for your product.People are probably paying for $1000 for Sublime (see screenshot below). God bless 'em.I think you're going to see a lot of indiehackers/solopreneurs use this model.Especially as AI drives the cost of building software business so down.The way to do it (you can bookmark this):1. Launch new product2. For beta release make it pay as you want3. Drive buzz4. PrintSo, this way, you've creating scarcity for people to try the product. And that's exactly what you want in a beta period.You can keep pay as you want as your business model, or move to traditional monthly subscriptions once you're out of beta.Win-win.It would be cool if the big tech players will play catch up on this model.Imagine if Figma or Notion or even Google launch a product that would be pay what you want?I'd say sign me up, pal.What do you think of "pay what you want"?

Just got an email from Notion – they're hiking prices by 20%. Ouch.This isn't just Notion - it’s a trend. SaaS companies are jacking up prices by 10-30% overnight, expecting you to just deal with it.Sure, if they’re delivering that much extra value, it’s a no-brainer. But let’s be real – many aren’t, and it makes you want to jump ship.Two trends happening with SaaS and how to take advantage:Trend #1: The rise of the low-cost SaaS.I call it the wholesalification of SaaS (think Costco) They'll offer the same (if not better) services at lower prices. SaaS is hitting its own Costco phase.  Thanks to AI, copying a software product is almost becoming free. It won't be perfect. But it'll be pretty darn good. 90% of the same features.So, why stick to Slack when there's a more wallet-friendly option out there? Take Zoho, for example. They've mastered the art of taking hit SaaS products and selling them for less. $1B ARR with 50 products, 15,000 employees, 100M+ users, is probably worth $50B based in India (far from Silicon Valley) and never raised $1 from anyone. Goals. How to do it: 1. Make a list of vertical software companies 2. Prioritize by need and lifetime value of customer 3. Clone yet create beautiful brand, copy, design, community  (or just localize it to certain geographies)4. Offer product at 50%+ less Trend #2: Pay Per Task or Lifetime DealsNobody wants another subscription right now. We’re all in subscription hell.Sure, if it’s dirt cheap, we might bite. But for most SaaS products, it’s worth considering lifetime or yearly deals (ditch the monthly plans).Lots of companies are trying lifetime deals, and they might lose money by year 3. You don’t want that. But if you can make it work, people will flock to you.Then there's pay-per-usage (or pay-per-task). As AI agents become more popular, pay-per-task will outshine usage-based pricing.Here’s my playbook if I were competing in SaaS:1. Find a popular niche SaaS app. Incubate or acquire.2. Compete on business model (lifetime deal or pay-per-task).You'd be surprised at the buzz these models generate. People love talking about them because they’re sick of being buried in monthly subscriptions.If you made it this far, I put together a database of 30+ free startup ideas I love (including SaaS)  for the taking.https://lnkd.in/eEQwvrCu So, i'll end with this:It's one of my biggest learnings in my 20s.When trends push people away, that's your signal to pull them in. Create for the overlooked, and watch the magic happen.You might not create the next Notion, but you might create the next Zoho.Enjoy.

The best marketing people I've worked with have 5 core skills in common. Let’s see if this describes you:1. You know how to write for the internet (virality).Crafting headlines that hook, stories that stick, and messages that move. It’s not about writing essays; it’s about creating content that goes viral. You understand the power of a well-placed tweet, a catchy blog post, or a viral video.2. You know how to throw a good party (community).Building a brand is like hosting a killer party. You create an environment where people feel welcome, engaged, and excited to be there. You understand the importance of community and know how to foster connections. You’re the person who brings people together, both online and offline.3. You’re the internet's creative director (short-form video).You get what makes people stop scrolling on short form video. You know the difference between when something should be overly-produced or raw and real. You create hooks that grab attention in the first 3 seconds. You obsess about retention curves. TikToks, Reels, YouTube Shorts – you master them all.4. You experiment. A lot.The best marketers are mad scientists. You’re constantly testing new ideas, analyzing results, and iterating. You’re not afraid to fail because you know each failure brings you closer to success. You run A/B tests, try out new platforms, and aren’t afraid to take risks.5. You have good taste in the niche.Good taste is about knowing what’s cool before it’s cool. You have a finger on the pulse of your niche, knowing what trends are emerging, and you can curate content and experiences that resonate with your audience. You’re not just following trends; you’re setting them.If you’re nodding along, you’re on the right path. But if you’re missing one of these, it’s time to level up.Start writing every day. Tweet, blog, vlogging. Practice makes perfect.Host events. Start small. Virtual meetups, webinars, or even Twitter Spaces. Get a feel for what your audience enjoys.Run experiments. A/B test everything. Headlines, images, content formats. Learn what works and what doesn’t.Cultivate taste. Follow industry leaders, stay updated on trends, and expose yourself to a variety of content. Develop a sense for what’s next.In today’s world, being a great marketer means being versatile. You need to be a writer, a host, an experimenter, and a tastemaker. And it's worth it.A good marketer is more powerful today than ever. You've got AI and no-code tools just waiting for you.You've got billions of people on social waiting for you to reach them. Startups scale faster than ever.It's a beautiful thing.

Inflation is killing the big 200+ person wedding. Who wants to blow $100,000 on a single day? New trend alert: Micro weddings (and 2 startup ideas worth taking)I got married recently. No hundred-person guest list. No fancy venue. Just 14 people, including my wife and me.It was intimate. It was personal. It was perfect.We had dinner at our favorite French restaurant. Steak frites and red wine. That’s it. Wouldn't change a thing. And guess what? We’re not alone. Micro-weddings are trending, especially in major cities like NYC, LA etcWith costs per guest soaring over $1,000 (thanks, inflation), couples are saying "I don't" to big, expensive weddings.Here’s some ideas around the trend with low risk, high rewardStartup idea #1: Airbnb Experiences but for Micro-WeddingsAirbnb probably does $1B/year on their experiences (my best projection), but don't cover micro-weddings. Imagine getting married in the Sequoias, surrounded by towering trees. Or upstate NY, surrounded by rolling hills.All for just $5,000. A Reddit post went viral where a couple broke down their $23,000 micro-wedding in LA. This validates the idea.Create a micro-wedding planning agency. Offer all-inclusive packages that streamline the process.One company, Our Little Wedding, is already doing it in San Francisco. They offer elopement packages starting at $5,000.You get a private ceremony, photography, florals, dinner, and a cake. All in a stunning location.The best part? Couples feel like they’re saving money. They’re happy to spend $5k when they thought they’d spend $50k.Over time, you become the Airbnb Experiences for micro-weddings. Expand beyond micro-weddings eventually. Who knows? Maybe sell to Airbnb for $100M.How to get started:1) Identify unique venues. Think outside the box – gardens, libraries, rooftops.2) Create a killer website with SEO-optimized content about micro-weddings.3) Run targeted ads on Instagram and Pinterest. Show off stunning micro-wedding visuals Okay, I'll give you another startup idea that might get your creative juices flowing.Startup idea #2: Micro-Wedding Content HubStart a website that’s the ultimate resource for everything micro-weddings.This is part of a bigger trend which is there's too much info out there. People want taste and curation. How to get started:1) Curate inspirational stories and real wedding examples. 2) Offer planning guides, checklists, and vendor directories. 90% in short form video.3) Monetize through affiliate/paid memberships.So, here's the blueprint how to create these types of businesses:1) Observe trends IRL2) Use Google Trends to find new related trends3) Use Reddit to validate the idea and decide geography to launch with 4) Build audience (short form video) to drive traffic/clarify offer5) Use AI/No-code to launch mvp6) Start printing, start iterating.Want more ideas? 30+ free startup ideas here https://lnkd.in/dGt8Cch4Free for now, not forever.

In 2013, at 23, I felt on top of the world. I'd just sold my company for $5M. Well, kinda. I'll tell you the story of how I lost it all.The $5M was in stock in a VC-backed company. But not just any stock.This company wasn't just any company.The company was doing $35M in revenue, with 70% gross margins.It was backed by Silicon Valley's who's who. I was living the dream. Or so I thought.My thinking was simple: Worst case? We'd cut staff, print $20M/year. And that rate, I'd easy be able to get my $5M of stock out, maybe even more. How could it go wrong? Spoiler alert: It did. Lol.Slowly, then all at once, we became a zombie company.Revenue started declining. Growth stalled. VCs lost interest.Here's the thing about the VC model. They care about growth and the next big unicorn.We looked like a donkey with a party hat.Suddenly, no one wanted to fund us. We had to sell. Fast. We found a buyer. People congratulated us. But I knew the truth: This wasn't a success.The outcome? We got nothing. Zip. Nada. My $5M paper fortune? Gone with the wind.But here's the silver lining: I learned this lesson at 23, not 43.Fast forward to today:I run a different kind of company. We're profitable. We grow steadily. No VC money. No paper valuations.The best part of my job now is sending out profit shares. 2x a year.Our team's reaction is priceless: "Wow, thank you! This is real?"They're used to VC-backed startups:1. Equity worth millions (on paper)2. Promises of future riches3. Reality - 90%+ of the time worth nothingI've been there, worn the t-shirt. VC equity is just gravy. Maybe it pays off, probably not.But profit shares? That's real money.In your bank account. Buy a car. Put a down payment on a house. Live your life now, not in some hypothetical future.This is why we're seeing the rise of the dividend startup. More and more people are choosing real money over paper unicorns.Here's my lesson learned:Build a business that prints cash, not promises. Focus on profitability, not vanity metrics. Grow steadily, not at all costs.Your team will thank you. Your stress levels will thank you. Your bank account will definitely thank you.Am I grateful for my $5M lesson? Absolutely. It shaped who I am today.So here's to failing young, learning fast, and building businesses that matter.Real value. Real profits. Real impact.I'm not saying you can't build a VC-backed business and build wealth. You totally can.But the odds are stacked against you.And most employees think when they join a VC-backed rocketship, that their stock is as good as gold.It usually isn't. Sharing this story in case it's useful to someone.The rise of the dividend startup isn't just coming.It's here.--Woah, thank you! Let me introduce you to your new mentor.You don’t need a billionaire mentor. Your mentor is the market.It’s taking an idea, and putting it out there.Seeing what people think. Or the just ignoring it altogether.That’s the mentor you need.So many people are waiting for the perfect mentor to guide them, to validate their ideas, to show them the way.What I love about the "market mentor"The market doesn’t sugarcoat or give you vague advice. It gives you raw, unfiltered feedback. It’s about taking an idea, putting it out there, and observing the reaction.Will people notice? Will they care? Will they engage?The market tells you what works and what doesn’t, and it does so without bias. It’s in the conversion rates of your ads, the engagement of your content, and the sales of your products. These metrics are your lessons.Every piece of feedback from the market helps you refine your intuition, sharpening your sense of what resonates and what falls flat. This process of iteration and adaptation builds a kind of wisdom that no single mentor could impart.The best advice comes from the trenches. Mentors often provide insights that are biased, outdated, and not tailored to your unique situation. They give second-hand advice that lacks the immediacy and relevance of real-world experience. The market, however, offers personalized mentorship. It’s your constant, unbiased advisor, giving you feedback that’s specific to your context and challenges.True mastery comes from engaging directly with reality, not from second-hand advice. The market is brutal, but it’s honest. It guides you through its reactions, teaching you more than any individual could.In the end, the market’s feedback is the most reliable mentor you’ll ever have. Trust it, learn from it, and let it shape your path.That’s all you need.Meet your new mentor. Say hello.Not what you thought they'd look like.But probably better.I'm doing a live startup ideas brainstorm today at 1p EST. Bring your ideas and me and 100+ other people will give you feedback.Or just come to listen in. https://lnkd.in/eyh7Mh4c Don't forget to subscribe here so you don't miss it: https://lnkd.in/ebpMJaHS

How to win in your 20s (read if you're any age):1. Don’t send angry emails/texts. Wait 24 hours. Eat, sleep, chill and remember that it’s not worth it2. Be a YouTube. You’re young, you know how to film well. Pick a niche, share 1 video a day, and let it compound. By 30, you have 100k subs3. Move to a big city. Don’t have to live there forever, but being in NYC or SF even for a short while will pay you back like crazy in your 30s.4. Be a generalist. The internet belongs to people who understand design, copy, paid ads, new technologies.5. Accept the days. Good days, bad days. Being okay with the randomness of life.6. Launch one new thing per year. It’s the only way to really learn to become a generalist.7. Do everything you can to not get into debt.8. Get insanely good at cold DMs.9. Build a bunch of internet MRR (monthly recurring revenue). Don’t rush into building a VC-backed startup. Your odds of building your nest egg that way are tiny with VC. For 99% of people, securing the bag will be a weight off your shoulders.10. Buy a high-quality set of headphones. When the beats are hitting, you’ll be more inspired to create and publish your work on the internet.11. Be addicted to real dopamine, not digital dopamine. Laughing with friends. Seeing a sunrise. That’s the real stuff.12. Create a "failure resume". Document your mistakes and what you learned from them. This helps normalize failure and turn it into a powerful tool for growth. You'll read it and be reminded.13. Write a weekly reflection. Spend 10 minutes every Sunday to reflect on the past week. What went well? What didn’t? What can you improve? 14. Sacrificing your reputation in the short term is always a bad idea.15. Your 20s are about variety. To learn what you like/dislike. The rest of your life will be to apply those learnings.16. Learn to cook a few staple meals. Not only will this save you money, but it’s also a valuable life skill. 17. Turn your quirks into assets. If you have a unique hobby or an unusual skill, showcase it. 18. Know that other people’s negativity is not yours. There are many insecure, sad people on this planet. Their sadness comes out in strange ways.19. Travel often but have a home base. Home base keeps you grounded, travel keeps you evolving.20. You don’t need the last word.21. Fruit is as good as candy22. Create a personal mission statement. Clarify what you stand for and what you want to achieve in your life. It’s OK if you change it23. Surround yourself with people who think big. If you can’t find them, listen to their pods/read their books24. Don't get a "safe" job at a big company. 500k tech workers have gotten laid off since 2022. Join a smaller company and soak up as much as you can learn.25. Be kind, trust your gut, work hard and you'll do wellIf this spoke to you, find guides of how to win on the internet/life at gregisenberg.com and subscribe.

Today, I met an entrepreneur who shared a simple clear framework for founders about "startup exits". There are 3 types of exits:1) Car Changing Money – Enough to upgrade your ride.2) House Changing Money – Enough to change your address.3) Life Changing Money – Enough to redefine your trajectory.It’s a clever distinction that got me thinking deeper about the paths laid before us as entrepreneurs.- Venture-backed startups—the ones that headline news stories—offer a roughly 20% shot at life-changing money, the kind that alters everything.But what's often glossed over is the silent majority, 80% by count, who after perhaps 7 years, have little to show but modest pay and burgeoning grey hairs. It’s a high-stakes game where the house often wins.- Cash-flowing startups — Initially, your indie cash-flowing products won't turn heads. A product doing $1k a month in MRR might elicit a patronizing "that's cute" from the venture crowd. But this just the seedling from which greater growth can sprout. As you add products, expand from a solopreneur to a multipreneur, these numbers can balloon—$10k, $100k, $1M monthly.With no venture capitalist, you’re forced to build a fundamentally profitable business. This not only fuels growth but also sweetens the pot at exit. Cash-flowing assets become coveted treasures, especially in bear markets where they're as rare as water in a desert. And with a cleaner cap table, getting these deals done are way more easy.Contrast this with venture-backed ventures during bear markets, mergers and acquisitions dry up, and without perfect timing, many are left stranded without an exit, just out of reach of the runway.So, as you plot your course, ask yourself what you’re optimizing for: Is it the car, the house, or life itself? Each choice carries its own set of risks and rewards, each path a different reflection of what success looks like to you.I’ve come to realize, the less obvious paths often lead to the most interesting destinations.So, all that to say…Decide what you’re trying to optimize for.Car, house, or life-changing money.

RIP"But they failed at that particular place and timeWith a particular team, strategy and tacticsThere's some gold in these startup graveyards.More gold than we give them credit for.All that's new is old.Don't get me wrong...I'd rather buy a business that is firing on all cylinders. 12 ideas, opportunities and things I’m thinking about right now:1. Finding mispriced assets. Is this business worth 2X EBITDA or 6X? In an AI world, some businesses are worth a whole lot less or a whole lot more than we think.  That spread is your retirement.2. Data is the new oil. NewsCorp did a $250M deal with OpenAI. Reddit inked $60M/year with Google. What non-obvious data sources will be valuable to LLMs in the future? Think about the unique data you have or can access.3. Localizing apps. I found an app crushing it in Pakistan that would thrive in the US. No need to reinvent the wheel. Just localize and scale. Check app store charts for different countries and bring validated products to new markets.4. The anti-Mr Beast strategy. Micro-influence > mass appeal. Small, loyal followings can be as powerful as large audiences. Creators with 10K real fans often make more impact (and money) than those with millions of passive viewers. Depth over breadth. Sleep better at night.5. The Elon effect. Fire 90% of your team and watch productivity soar. Elon did it at X, and it’s a masterclass in cutting dead weight. Most tech companies are just burning cash on mediocrity. It makes you think about your own companies. How much bloat is in your organization?6. Silent entrepreneurs.I met entrepreneurs who don't even have an X account quietly building empires. I call them virgin entrepreneurs—multi-million dollar businesses, zero social media. Focus on building, not broadcasting. Being silent has its advantages.7. Resurrection of old products. An Australian group covered an old Cranberries’ song “Linger” and got 100M+ views. Some old products are ripe to go viral with the right twist. Dust off forgotten ideas and give them new life.8. Brute force audience building. In 2007, I replied to every comment on my blog. It worked. Engage relentlessly and build a loyal audience brick by brick. Taylor Swift did it. I recently started replying to every YouTube comment. It works.9. Pay per outcome (PPO). The new business model, accelerated by AI driving costs down. If you can’t prove value, you don’t get paid. Industries ripe for disruption with a pay-per-outcome model. Compete with SaaS by going pay-per-outcome.10. Bullish on YouTube. TikTok’s potential ban will make YouTube hot again. New features like Shopify integration allow creators to monetize directly. Expect a wave of ecommerce & creator millionaires thanks to this integration.11. The Half-Life of virality. Viral sensations used to last months. Now, maybe days. More viral hits lose steam quickly. 12. Embrace "being bad". I’ve failed countless times, but each failure was a step toward mastery. Embrace the process.Resources for you:1) Frameworks for how to win on the internet: subscribe at gregisenberg.com (free to subscribe) 2) 5+ free cash-flowing startup ideas per week on my YouTube https://lnkd.in/ebpMJaHS (free to subscribe)

I learned something new the other day. There are indie Amazon Kindle authors making $200k+/month via EXTREMELY niche books.And they’re not just guessing what to write– they’re using secret data tools like "Publisher Rocket".Let's dig in.I learned this while talking to Dickie Bush and Nicolas Cole on today's episode of The Startup Ideas podcast Recently, entrepreneurs/authors are crushing it in underserved self-publishing niches. Cole dropped a gem of an example:The “lit RPG” (role-playing game literature) subgenre on Amazon Kindle. Top titles like “The Way of the Shaman” are pulling in $250k+ per month. Who knew?Readers devour these books faster than a power-leveling wizard, but the quality is like a Level 1 goblin.There’s a golden opportunity for a niche publishing company with better writing, cover designs, and branding to dominate “lit RPGs”.It got me thinking – what other untapped niches are out there waiting for someone to level up the content?Here’s how you can find out:Publisher Rocket:A data tool that shows estimated sales, search volume, and competition for any Kindle book or category. How it works:1. Scope Out Categories. Find estimated monthly sales and revenue for top books.2. Analyze Keywords. Check search volume and competition to find the "competitive score" for each keyword.3. Hunt Trending Niches. Look for high-demand, low-competition areas. This is the sweet spot.4. Reverse-Engineer Success.  Study top authors in the niche, their sales, and revenue.5. Data-Driven Creation. Craft a book for an underserved niche with explosive potential.Publisher Rocket is like having a secret agent in the Kindle store. Its an unfair advantage. I don't know how long this arbitrage will last. It’s a game-changer for finding what readers want, what's selling, and where the untapped markets are.But don’t stop there. It's about dialing in your audience targeting.Cole pointed out that women are the majority of fiction readers, but most lit RPGs cater to men. Not only is “lit RPG” an underserved niche, but female readers within it are also underserved.This strategy applies to any niche. Find an opportunity in vegan dessert cookbooks? Niche down to recipes for busy parents who need quick, healthy treats for kids.When hunting niches, look for overlooked audience segments. Then, leverage that IP for TV, movies, ecommerce etcEndless opportunities.Hope this was valuable. Comment/repost if it was.TLDR;They use data intel tools like Publisher Rocket to unearth:- Huge reader demand- Low competition- Untapped profit - Niche down further to unserved audiences (like female LitRPG readers).Take notes, all.Full episode is LIVE (plus other bonus cash-flowing startup ideas) below:https://lnkd.in/eS9rb5dXhttps://lnkd.in/eXyh8Zhshttps://lnkd.in/eUJMNz_K

I’ll tell you a story I haven’t told many people…I'm 18, bank account dwindling, and desperate for a job. I applied to 100 jobs and got zero offers. They said I didn’t have enough experience or my French wasn’t good enough. The hopelessness was real.So, I reached out to internet companies in SF/NYC."Hey, would you pay me $2/lead? No risk to you."It was 2008, during the great financial crisis. Companies were looking to cut costs, and this was attractive. Mobile/social was just becoming a thing. New apps needed users.The first few hundred emails were ignored. Finally, one company said yes. I made $100 that month. Not exactly balling out, but it was a start. I bought a pair of cool shoes with it. Sweetest shoes I ever bought.Every app needed users, and I knew how to get them. I could scale this. I hired two friends, trained them on the pitch, and paid them $1/lead. The margins were thin, but we started pulling in volume.One day, I found a goldmine—a venture-backed startup scaling fast. They needed users and had the budget.I pitched them: "$2/lead? Let's scale to 1,000 leads a week." This was Zynga. They had just put out Farmville and were looking to grow users.They bit. Suddenly, I was making $2,000 a week. I dropped out of college.We experimented with Facebook ads, forum postings, and influencer marketing. The results were wild. Facebook ads were literally $0.05 per click!In '08, we built an iPhone app (before the App Store) to ping us every lead we generated. On my 18th birthday, it dinged every few secs.In 6 months, we were generating over 20,000 leads a month and running a mini lead-gen empire. I was still living at my parents' house.But the $$ wasn’t the most interesting part. We were learning skills that would be invaluable—growth hacking, community mgmt, copywriting etcFast forward to today, and I've built and sold multiple companies. But it all started with that $2/lead hustle during the worst economic downturn of our generation.Moral of the story:When the world goes to hell, look for opportunities. Innovate. Be relentless. Your big break might be just an email away.I felt pretty hopeless back then. But the cool part about the internet is the lack of gatekeepers.Not too long ago...- You had to get press to get customers.- You needed VCs to build a product.- You needed a degree to get that job.There was always a gatekeeperNot anymore. Tons of people sit on the sidelines. They aren't shipping.But it's not because they can't. They totally could. Especially with the cost of launching anything being so cheap. They just don't realize the gates have recently become wide open.It fires me up.So, stop waiting for permission. The gates are open. Just walk through. --Enjoyed this? Here’s a free billion-dollar startup idea for you. Reinvent Microsoft Teams or Slack...But, instead of charging $4-$8 per user, charge per message or per new channel.Enterprise messaging is a multi-billion dollar market, but it's broken. CFOs are tearing their hair out trying to cut costs. Employees get mini heart attacks every time they’re added to another channel. It’s chaos.Imagine this...fewer messages, fewer channels. Meetings are more productive, focus time is sacred, and companies save a ton of money. Everyone’s happier. The entire brand is about quiet and happiness. You make the logo a freaking bright yellow sunshine.All features are designed to be more productive. Maybe you even partner with productivity influencer like an Ali Abdaal or Tim Ferriss So, this idea of taking market share from Slack/Teams is top of mind right now. Some of my fav entrepreneurs are going after it.Jason Fried launched Campfire with a $399 lifetime deal. Amazing, but not everyone wants to host their own software. Too much hassle for most.David Sacks tried Glue AI, adding more features but sticking with the same old $7/month model. Competing on features is tough when you're competing against Slack. They've already shiped AI-powered search, conversation summaries and recaps.My last company was a group chat app. Competing with WhatsApp, Discord, and others in a feature race was brutal. Lesson learned for me:You never want to be in a feature race unless you have endless funding.Here’s the takeaway..Sometimes, it’s not about reinventing the product. It’s about changing the business model.Imagine the CFO of a mid-sized company discovering they can save thousands by switching to a pay-per-use model. No more per-user licenses. Teams are less distracted, more productive. The CFO will push for this. Teammates will push for it. That's how you build sales momentum.I hope someone takes this free idea... or at least finds another category and just flips the business model on its head.Agree or disagree with me?We can make the comment section a nice creative zone.And if you like startup ideas, click the youtube link below for ~5 free startup ideas per week.https://lnkd.in/ebpMJaHS

I saw so many typos in a creator's post recently. It went viral—millions of views. Typos everywhere.I let out a sigh of relief. I knew he didn’t use ChatGPT. Or did he?It got me thinking...If people think your content, copy, or designs were made by AI, you've already lost.Humans crave the human touch, authenticity, and the real deal. It's human nature.I'm starting to see brands use AI in a pretty tasteless way.The CMO thinks no-one can tell that those images were created by DALL-E or Midjourney. People can tell.AI is powerful. It can create, predict, and optimize. But it lacks soul. When your audience sniffs out AI, trust plummets. And that's pretty hard to regain.In the future, the best brands/creators will be those who master AI, not just use it. They'll blend tech and humanity so seamlessly that you can't tell where one ends and the other begins.But let's not forget, human creators can hit crazy scale without AI. I think of Moots, a high-end bicycle builder that handcrafts titanium bikes tailored to each rider's specs. They are the anti-mainstream bike and do $5M+ revenue per year. Very bespoke, made-in-the-USA bikes.My point is being human-made, not mainstream, is also an opportunity to create profitable businesses. When everyone is zigging, zagging is an equally good strategy.Prediction: we'll see an influx of "human made" products, content etc.And they might end up being even more profitable than the AI-first ones.Moots carved out a niche by being authentic and personal in a world of mass production.So here's my current thinking on this whole topic:Imagine a world where AI does the heavy lifting, freeing you to add the magic. That’s the sweet spot. But it's a fine line. Lean too hard on AI, and you risk becoming a faceless algorithm.Someone will respond to this and say:"well, AI is going to get so good no one will notice".I'm a/cc as the next Twitter person. But I believe humans will always play a huge role in the equation.Because ultimately we're selling to other humans.The winners of this era....They'll be the storytellers who use AI as a tool, not a crutch. They'll deliver human experiences enhanced by technology. Nail that blend, and you're unstoppable.The future of content: Come for the creator, stay for the typos.

I've built an 8 figure holding company with $0 of outside capital called Late Checkout. Today, I’ll share our playbook:Step 1: Find audienceWe focus on influential, high value customer audiences.We’re like the anti-Mr.Beast. Less glory but I’m okay with it.We get ideas for those on what’s trending on places like Reddit and X. We use automation and AI to get those insights quickly and clearly.We observe what’s beginning to take off. Write it down.And most importantly, we ask "why now".Our most successful businesses had a strong why now.We write these ideas in our idea pages within Notion.Review it weekly.Step 2: social accountInstead of building a product that we sell first, we begin with a social account.Counter-intuitive, I know.But our thesis is that distribution is harder than building a product.We look at what other accounts in the space are doing.And try to do the opposite. The opposite is an important point because you're trying to create "scroll stopping" content. If it looks like everything else, they'll keep scrolling. Tactically, that might mean going more visual. Or telling stories that aren’t told.We get good at finding that format.And only focus on 1 platform.Multiple platforms at this stage is a distraction.Step 3: grow accountWe wait until we get to 10,000 followers before we usually build anything.In B2B, if you have 10,000 followers, you're the Mr. Beast of your category.10,000 potential customers is massive.Each platform has unique ways to grow.We’re particularly excited about You Tube right now.The “hack” right now is longer form, more raw videos and posting daily.Step 4: Free communityPeople don’t want another community.But they do want value.We overload them with value in exchange for their email/number.What’s worked really well is creating communities around “challenges”.Example: Join the 90 day keto challenge.Best part of this step is having this group of customers tell you what to build.And if you don't want to build a community, that's okay.Build a bunch of lead magnets.Step 5: Build a productWe don’t spend more than 30 days to build a product.Start small.Sometimes we’ll partner with existing business here. Or incubate something very small with a leading founder who's been in this space before.This has worked well.Step 6: Product/market fit.Now, product/market fit starts hitting and high fives all around.Copycats come in. But it’s okay.We keep going. The community keeps telling us what to build.And we’ve got systems in places to build quickly, test, learn and make it beautiful.It compounds all of it. The audience, the community, the product.Step 7: the futureOnce the product is really at product/market fit.We start thinking about adjacent products. We either buy/incubate those.That's the basic playbook. Hope it was helpful.Tomorrow, I'm co-hosting a live workshop on finding your audiencehttps://lu.ma/05esbrvx

I was part of startups that raised billions of VC in my 20s in Silicon Valley and didn't make much money. Here's the story and why it matters to you:1. VCs tell you to dedicate your life to the business, but they take August off.2. VCs tell you that you need to go big or go home, but their business is a collection of many bets3. VCs tell you it's all about team, but it’s common to replace a founder/ceo.4. VCs tell you to be lean and agile, but they’ll drown you in cash if it means a big exit.5. VCs tell you to maintain a work-life balance, but smile when you send emails at midnight.6. VCs tell you to own your niche, but often nudge you towards mass markets before you're ready.7. VCs tell you to measure everything, but their decision to fund often hinges on intangible 'gut feelings'.Am I wrong? Be honest.Now, I don't think all VCs are the same, just like all entrepreneurs aren't the same.But the problem isn't in VCs, it's two things:1) Some businesses need venture funding to thrive. The SpaceX type businesses or Uber type businesses2) VCs aren't 100% aligned with founders (especially first time founders).Let me break it down.They are incentivized for you to grow valuation. And sell or go public one day.But if you get an M&A offer that might be life-changing for you and your family? They might say don't do it.That happened to me. I had an M&A offer that was life changing when I was 22 years old. I would return 3x the amount I raised. Not bad right?I brought the deal to my lead VC. And he wouldn't sign the paperwork."I'm not thinking big enough. Imagine what I can get in 5 years. Forget 3x, think 30x".I'll write about that story in a future newsletter post (gregisenberg dot com).So, for most entrepreneurs, I say make your money doing bootstrapped. Support your family. Buy your first house. Retire your parents. Do whatcha gotta do.That "makes a ding in the universe" in a different way. It makes a ding in your universe.Don't be shy to share this.Let's have an honest convo about this.If you agree with me, here's some free resources for you:1. The future of building startups (blueprint to building a startup right now): https://lnkd.in/ea9_ZQEU2. Free 5 day course on the ACP funnel (building businesses around internet audiences and community) --> https://lnkd.in/eYnzEi9BEnjoy.

Why do we call $1B startups unicorns? Nowadays, when I hear someone has raised hundreds of millions of dollars, I cringe. Employees probably won't make a $1. That's the harsh truth.When founders say they've raised a small number with a great business, I’m impressed. When founders say they've raised nothing with a great business, I'm even more impressed.No dilution, no investor updates, no external pressure.People call companies that have hit the magical $1B valuation mark "unicorns" because of how dreamy it is to hit that milestone.I don't know about you but it feels like the tides are shifting. Cash flow > valuation.The real unicorns are the startups that have raised $0, small teams, generate $10M-$1B year of revenue, have brands people love and are cash machines.Usually, these founders have multiple products, multiple companies, multiple income streams.Sounds pretty awesome to me.If it does to you too, here's some free resources for you:1.
